Column: 679

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EXTRADITION TREATY AND DEFENCE COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH INDONESIA

(Implications and issues)

     1.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs what are the implications of the extradition treaty signed with Indonesia and whether it will strengthen bilateral ties.

 

     2.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will explain the issues taken into consideration in the signing of the extradition treaty and defence cooperation agreement with Indonesia.

 

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed) (for the Minister for  Foreign Affairs):   Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of Minister George Yeo who is overseas. I

Column: 680

will be addressing the Parliamentary Questions submitted by Ms Irene Ng and Ms Lee Bee Wah together.

 

     Mr Speaker:  You are taking Question Nos. 1 and 2 together?

 

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed:  Yes.  Sir, the signing of the Extradition Treaty (ET) and the Defence Cooperation Agreement (DCA) last month was in line with the decision taken by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono in October 2005 to negotiate both the ET and DCA in parallel and conclude them as a package.

 

     Since October 2005, there were several rounds of negotiations on the ET and DCA. Officials on both sides worked hard and made progress. Given that both agreements involve many complex issues, significant give-and-take was required on both sides. On 23rd April 2007, the Foreign and Defence Ministers, as well as armed forces chiefs, from both sides met to discuss the outstanding issues in Singapore. In a spirit of compromise and friendship, both sides sorted out their differing positions vis-a-vis the various issues and reached agreement on the ET and DCA as a political package. This means that the two signed Agreements contained a carefully negotiated balance of benefits. These agreements are good for both countries. Now that they have been signed, the next step is for both agreements to be ratified by Singapore and Indonesia through our own procedures.  As they are a package, we have agreed that they should come into force together. 

 

     Sir, Indonesia, as we all know, is a close neighbour. Our relations are extensive and broad-based. It is therefore in our interest to find opportunities to work with them where we can. The ET and DCA will help lay a strong foundation for further cooperation in the future. The

Column: 681

ET will strengthen our cooperation with Indonesia in tackling crime and other offences, including acts of terrorism, in accordance with the domestic laws of each country. Similarly, we would like to enhance the enduring defence ties between the SAF and the Indonesian Armed Forces (or TNI) and strengthen the professional bonds and interoperability of the two militaries through the DCA.

 

     When these agreements come into force, relations between Singapore and Indonesia will enter a new phase. But this does not mean that there will be no more bilateral issues. Indeed, signing an ET has removed a bone of contention in bilateral relations but it may also create other problems. For example, there are legal procedures and judicial processes which have to be followed when an extradition request is made. Indonesia's police and judicial processes will be subject to review by our judges and vice versa. It is therefore important that both sides understand this and allow the due process of law in each country to take its course.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, it is natural that differences in bilateral relations will arise from time to time between close neighbours. We can resolve them together, as long as we take the right perspective against the overall relationship.  This should also not stop us from finding ways to resolve these differences or explore new areas of cooperation on a "win-win" basis. The ET and DCA are  good examples of how our countries were able to tackle difficult issues and find mutually beneficial solutions.   I am therefore confident that Singapore-Indonesia relations will continue to mature and deepen.

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Sir, the Senior Minister of State said that the Extradition Treaty was negotiated in parallel with the Defence Cooperation

Column: 682

Agreement and concluded as a package.  But we have since learned that the DCA has hit some snags, there are several agreements which have not been signed, and there are problems arising from that.  Can I ask the Senior Minister of State whether this means that if the DCA and its implementing agreements are not signed as mutually agreed upon earlier, then the ET will be off?

 

     The other question is, why did we rush into signing the ET when the DCA has not been all tied up with all the "i"s dotted and the "t"s crossed?

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed:  As I have mentioned earlier, there was consensus and agreement between the two leaders of Indonesia and Singapore - Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Bambang Yudhoyono - that both will be taken together.  So, we are looking forward that both will be ratified.  There are some snags in terms of implementation issues, but we are waiting for the Indonesian side to conclude that, and we look forward to signing both together.  Our understanding is that, in fact, both will have to be signed together and both will be made applicable at the same time.

 

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State: since it was signed two months after the sand ban, did we sign it because we were under the pressure of the sand ban?  My next question is: what has we sacrificed or compromised in reaching this agreement?

 

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed:  I think sacrifices or compromises are part of any negotiations and relations.  In the case of Indonesia and Singapore, as I mentioned earlier, in fact, if we work on the basis of compromises and friendship, much can be achieved.  But specifically in answer to her question about sand, they are separate matters and are not linked.  As I recounted earlier, the decision to negotiate and

Column: 683

conclude both the ET and DCA as a package was made much earlier in October 2005.  The negotiations were already well advanced when land, sand and granite became an issue earlier this year.  It was a distraction but not related to these talks.

 

     The Indonesians have repeatedly stated that there is no ban on granite sales.  It is the prerogative of the Indonesian government to sell or not sell us sand so long as they comply with the WTO rules.  As you all know, and it has been reported before, we have made alternative arrangements for our sand supplies.

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:  Sir, the Senior Minister of State did not answer the question of why the rush to sign the ET, especially coming at a time when there was pressure over the land issue and sand ban, which might give some the impression that we are bowing to pressure, especially since the DCA has not been signed, sealed and delivered at the same time.  Why the rush?

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed:  To answer that question, there are others who are saying why it has taken so long.  We started back in 2005.  Many had, in fact, complained as though we were dragging our feet.  In fact, when both Ministers and the chiefs of the armed forces met - after the officials had not been able to come to any agreement - they were able to iron out the differences and even come to a conclusion. I do not know whether it was a surprise, but I think it was timely.  I do not think the sand and the granite issue which came just before that was the primary contribution towards the signing of the two agreements.

 

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong):  Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State whether the Extradition Treaty will undermine or, to use his own word, compromise Singapore's position as an

Column: 684

international financial centre, and whether Indonesians will hesitate to invest, put their money or buy property in Singapore because of this.

 

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed:  I think this question is best answered by MOF.  But this is the position we have made clear from the very beginning - that we, as a financial centre, stand on our merits and our own credible position as a financial hub.  And I do not think the signing of the ET will undermine that position.  In fact, on the contrary, I feel it might strengthen our position.

 

Column: 684

DEFENCE COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH INDONESIA

(Benefits)

     3.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Defence how the Defence Cooperation Agreement with Indonesia can improve the capability of the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and boost ties between the Indonesian Armed Forces (TNI) and SAF.    

 

     The Minister for Defence (Mr Teo Chee Hean):  Sir, the Defence Cooperation Agreement (DCA) is a strategic framework for mutually beneficial defence cooperation between Singapore and Indonesia.  The agreement provides for a balance of benefits to the SAF and TNI, and will promote closer relations, greater cooperation and interoperability between the two armed forces.

 

     Under the DCA, we will restart joint projects which the SAF and TNI find professional value in, including the Air Weapons Range and Air Combat Manoeuvring Range in Pekanbaru, and the use of a naval gunfire support scoring system in Pulau Kayu Ara in the South China Sea.  There will also be a new area of cooperation between the two armies with the development of facilities and infrastructure at the Baturaja Land Forces

Column: 685

Training Area in south Sumatra.  The SAF will benefit from having access to these facilities and being able to train alongside their Indonesian counterparts.  Such training opportunities will allow the SAF and TNI to develop professionally and enhance their interoperability, which has enabled both armed forces to work closely together in times of need.  We have seen them do so in instances such as in the search and recovery operations following the crash of SilkAir Flight MI 185 near Palembang in December 1997 and in the tsunami relief mission to Aceh in December 2004.

 

     In addition, we will continue to provide training assistance to the TNI through simulator training for their pilots, including the F-5, G-FET and Super Puma simulator training, and restarting professional courses like the Combined Fighter Weapons Instructor Course.  To date, over 250 TNI-AU pilots have undergone simulator training in Singapore, and 10 TNI-AU instructors have graduated from the Combined Fighter Weapons Instructor Course.  We will also continue to offer the TNI academic courses, such as scholarships to pursue postgraduate studies in Singapore at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy and the Rajaratnam School of International Studies, as well as English language courses at the Regional Language Centre (RELC).  To date, 12 TNI officers have graduated from postgraduate studies in Singapore, while 120 have gone through the English language course at RELC.  We will also provide the TNI with naval technical assistance and access to training facilities in Singapore.

 

     The SAF will benefit from having access to training areas in Indonesia for the conduct of military training and exercises.  While the SAF has access to training areas and facilities in many countries, the DCA will allow the SAF to

Column: 686

conduct useful training closer to Singapore.

 

     But, Sir, most importantly, the DCA will allow us to strengthen the strategic relationship between the SAF and TNI, which goes back more than 30 years.  The TNI is an important institution in Indonesia. The DCA will promote closer interaction and interoperability between the two armed forces, enabling them to work effectively together in times of need.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:  May I ask the Minister for an update of the status of the three service level agreements that have not been signed and whether this would impede the ability for us to move forward on closer cooperation with TNI under the DCA? 

 

      My second question is this.  Some critics in Indonesia have made out the DCA to be an agreement which could compromise its sovereignty and they took issue in particular with the clause which allows Singapore to include a third party in its military training in Indonesia.  Can I ask the Minister whether we have similar training agreements with other countries?  Because I know that MINDEF has very close relations with countries all over the world.

 

 

 


     Mr Teo Chee Hean:  Sir, the DCA is the overall governing document specifying the whole range of cooperative activities envisaged between the SAF and the TNI.  And then there are implementing arrangements.  The three agreements that have yet to be signed are three implementing arrangements regarding specific areas of cooperation.  These were all agreed to as part of the package of agreements settled between the two countries on 23rd April 2007.  Indonesia has asked for some variations to the various agreements and we have conveyed to them our views on this matter.  We are still in discussion, so I will

Column: 687

rather not get into any details on this matter.

     Ms Ellen Lee (Sembawang):  With the close cooperation between SAF and the TNI on sharing of facilities and knowledge as well, in the event that relationship between the two countries should be bad, which I hope do not happen, will that compromise the security of Singapore, because they would have knowledge of what we have and how we operate?  I would think that in times of warfare, that would be something dangerous.

    Mr Teo Chee Hean:  Mr Speaker, Sir, on the Defence Cooperation Agreement.  The defence relations between Indonesia and Singapore are excellent. And I would say that over the last three decades, the defence relationship between the TNI and SAF has, in fact, been a cornerstone of the overall relationship between Indonesia and Singapore.  And, historically, it has been good.  It started with the Navy having exercises with each other in 1974 - I have to think a little bit because I took part in this first exercise that was conducted between the TNI and the SAF and I had good memories of it - and we have strengthened our relationship since then.

 

    So I do not want to speculate on issues like the one that Ms Ellen Lee has raised.  But it is in order to strengthen this relationship between our two countries and the relationship between our two armed forces that both our countries have entered willingly and freely into this set of agreements that we have before us today.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:  The Minister has not answered my question on whether the military agreement that we have with Indonesia is similar in spirit and in terms of some the clauses with other countries that we have around the world.

 

    The second question is this.  The Minister has given us some updates on

Column: 688

the status of the service level in the implementing agreements.  Can I ask the Minister:  is it not quite uncharacteristic of our MINDEF to sign a DCA, and leaving some loose details still not tied up at the point of signing? Can I ask the Minister why did we go ahead to do that and now being faced with the problem of having to discuss further some possible review of agreements that we have reached before?

    Mr Teo Chee Hean:  Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said, the details of the DCA and the agreements are still not made public, so I do not want to go into the details and comparing one agreement with another agreement.  In any case, agreements made between countries and armed forces do differ depending on the circumstances.  So I do not want to go into the details and make comparisons.

 

    For the package of agreements which we settled on 23rd April, this included the three arrangements which are yet to be signed.  We had discussed whether to sign all the agreements together on 27th April and the Indonesians requested for the three arrangements to be signed on a separate day, ie, 7th May.  In the event that had to be postponed because there were some matters which, as I have explained earlier, the Indonesians have requested for some variations, and we have conveyed our views to the Indonesians and we are still in discussion on this matter.

Column: 688

TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE HANDICAPPED AND ELDERLY

      4.  Miss Penny Low asked the Minister for Transport (a) what has been done to further enhance the existing transportation infrastructure for the handicapped and elderly; and (b) how can infrastructure be designed such that it anticipates and meets the growing needs of the elderly, be it in MRT stations, bus terminals or overhead bridges.

Column: 689

     The Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Lim Hwee Hua) (for the Minister for Transport):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to update Miss Penny Low on the Land Transport Authority (LTA)'s initiatives to enhance the accessibility of our land transport infrastructure to meet the needs of the elderly and the less mobile.

 

    The LTA has completed a Station Upgrade Project begun in 2000 to enhance the accessibility of MRT stations along the North-South and East-West lines.  Lifts, tactile guidance systems and accessible toilets were installed.  Each station also had at least one entrance upgraded to be barrier-free for wheelchair users.  These features are already present in the stations on the North-East Line.

 

     LTA is currently reviewing whether some stations require more than one entrance with a lift to make it easier for our less mobile citizens to access our trains more conveniently.  Any enhanced standards would also apply to the Downtown Line.

 

      Wheelchair-accessible buses have been introduced progressively since June 2006.  They have been introduced on five bus routes identified in consultation with the voluntary welfare organisations and more will be rolled out.  Bus stops along such routes are also upgraded to ensure accessibility.  By 2010, 40% of our public bus fleet will be wheelchair accessible. 

 

     In December 2006, LTA launched a programme to implement barrier-free routes within a 400-metre radius of all MRT and LRT stations.  These measures include having an unobstructed pedestrian walkway wide enough for a wheelchair to pass, ensuring that the pavements are flush with the road surface, introducing ramps where necessary, and providing decision tactiles to guide the visually impaired at crossings and pedestrian overhead bridges.  

 

Column: 690

     In addition, LTA will also look at providing more traffic light crossings at suitable locations, as such crossings are more convenient for the elderly and less mobile. 

     LTA will continue to enhance our land transport system to meet the varied needs of our population as we move towards a more socially inclusive society.

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol):  Sir, the Minister of State mentioned that there will be enhanced traffic junctions to make it easier for the elderly to cross the road.  I am wondering whether there will also be plans to make the overhead bridges a lot more user-friendly with a slightly lower gradient and perhaps ramps by the side as well.

     Mrs Lim Hwee Hua:  Sir, essentially, LTA will build more signalised pedestrian crossings as these have proven to be more convenient for the elderly and the less able.  However, on stretches like expressways and main arterial roads where the speed is a lot higher, pedestrian overhead bridges would be used.  This is the guiding principle.  And where there are no land take constraints, ramps could be considered to also facilitate these movements. A lot of what is available is usually constrained by what is possible at the different sites, such as a more gradual gradient for the ramp and this would be taken into consideration whenever LTA decides to construct a pedestrian overhead bridge.

     Miss Penny Low:   Does it therefore imply that in places like new towns, in particular, there could be the possibility of building more graduated or low gradient overhead bridges?  On top of that, I would like to also ask two supplementary questions.  The Minister of State mentioned that 40% of the buses will be disabled-friendly by 2010.  May I ask if it is possible to accelerate that because to wait for the next five years, or maybe

Column: 691

even 10 years, to get 100% is actually a long wait for the disabled population.  On top of that, is it also possible to enlarge some of the pedestrian walkways, especially in new towns, so that they can also be wheelchair friendly?  One last supplementary question:  have the pedestrian crossings been effective because there had been a number of accidents in the past?  If it is not, are there plans for road safety education?

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua:  Mr Speaker, Sir, let me take the questions in turn.  Generally, where overhead bridges or signalised pedestrian crossings are built in densely built-up areas, the land take is really quite a severe constraint. Therefore, even though we can plan for new towns and accommodate some of the overhead bridges to provide for ramps, this will still be ultimately a balance between the other users of the overhead bridges as well as the elderly and the disabled.  A balance has to be struck because if the gradient is far too gentle, then all those who are more able will actually have to walk a fuller length of the ramp which then might defeat the whole purpose of facilitating a quick crossing of the road.

 

   As for the 40% target that we are reaching in 2010, this is really to accommodate the replacement programme of the buses as it is very expensive to replace all buses at one go. And this is already being funded by the Government in terms of providing the cost of equipping the buses with these ramps.  Miss Penny Low has also asked whether walkways could be wide enough to accommodate the needs of the wheelchair users. Again, this is a balance that we have to strike as it involves the allocation of space.  This applies equally to road space, space at the side table.  Generally, at the end of the day, it is a question of the constraints of the area and the needs of the different stakeholders.  And, by and large, for some of these where there are possibilities, then grassroots organisations would be involved in the

Column: 692

discussion of what might be the most appropriate for that particular situation.

 

    Finally, I think Miss Penny Low alludes to the point of public education and personal safety. The Government can only go so far as to provide the structures, such as signalised pedestrian crossings or overhead bridges.  But, ultimately, the responsibility is for each pedestrian to maintain his own personal safety and to look out for himself.  So you could have a signalised pedestrian crossing, but if the user does not want to wait and decides to jay walk across, then he is putting his own life in danger.

causeway bridge, dedicated lanes into and out of Resorts World and also road improvements within the Sentosa's internal network.  The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is also considering several improvements works on roads leading to Sentosa Island.  This may include widening works along Sentosa Gateway, Telok Blangah Road and Kampong Bahru Road.

    Dr Lam Pin Min (Ang Mo Kio):  Mr Speaker, I would like to ask the Minister of State two supplementary questions: firstly, are there plans to rejuvenate the ferry service to Sentosa or even consider a new ferry service from the mainland to the doorstep of the new Sentosa IR which may, hopefully, ease the land traffic demands?  And, secondly, has the Ministry ever considered introducing other alternative transport modalities such as heli-transportation to Sentosa?

SHORTAGE OF OFFICE SPACES

     6.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for National Development, in light of the redevelopment of buildings resulting in shortage of office spaces in the city area and spiralling rental increases, what plans are there to help businesses relocate and whether his Ministry will publish or give information on alternative availability of office spaces for small and medium-sized companies.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the current tightness in the office space market is due to high demand, which is driven by Singapore's robust economic growth over the last two years, coupled with low net supply due to the previous few years of slow growth, the conversion of office space to other uses and the redevelopment of office buildings.

     In fact, the increase in demand of 290,000 square metres in 2006 was the highest annual increase since year 2000.  On the other hand, because not many new office projects were initiated in the last few years, and with the conversion of some office buildings to other uses and the redevelopment of office buildings, the net additional supply of office space was low.  In 2005/2006, the supply increased by only 47,000 square metres.

     However, the situation is expected to improve in 2010 when a substantial amount of new supply, totalling about 330,000 square metres, comes on stream.  This includes 180,000 square metres of office space from Phase 1 of the Marina Bay Financial Centre.   MND will continue to release land at a steady pace via the Government Land Sales Programme, to ensure that there is

Column: 695

sufficient land for office developments in the longer term.

     In the meantime, the market is already making some adjustments to mitigate the current tight situation.  For example, some companies have started to reorganise their operations so that they can relocate either fully or partially out of the Central Area.  This will free up some office space in the city.


     Besides office buildings, space at business parks can also meet the needs of some companies.  Backroom operations and data centres of financial institutions or SMEs can be housed in such business park space.  For example, a new 20,000 square metres development has just been completed in Changi Business Park which can cater to such backroom user needs.  More business park space is expected to be completed over the next two to three years, to help meet the office space needs of suitable firms.

     Companies can also consider leasing vacant State buildings, such as office buildings or suitable old school buildings, which are immediately available and can be put to office use quickly.  SLA has made available some 51,000 square metres of such space.  More such properties suitable for office use will be made available in the next few months.

     To further ease the short-term shortage, URA will be identifying sites for the development of transitional offices.  These sites will be made available on short-term leases for the development of low-rise office buildings of about three to four storeys.  They can be built quickly in about one year and at relatively low cost, and can thus meet more immediate needs.  More details on the development of transitional offices will be made available shortly.

     Sir, measures to meet office demand in the short term will not be effective if

Column: 696

there is a continual depletion of office space through the conversion of existing office buildings to other uses.  This is taking place despite the tight office situation, especially within the Central Area.  As such, URA has announced earlier today that it will temporarily disallow conversion of office buildings to other uses in the Central Area until 31st December 2009.

     Let me explain the rationale for this move.  The conversion of office buildings in the Central Area worsens the current office situation in two ways.  Firstly, it immediately removes supply from the office stock, as buildings are demolished or closed for refurbishment.  Secondly, the decanted businesses exert additional demand as they have to look for alternative space to relocate their operations.

     Many of these buildings are in reasonably good condition and can still meet the needs of most office users, especially in the next two to three years.  While the Government does encourage building owners to rejuvenate and redevelop their older buildings, such redevelopment is not appropriate at this point in time.  It will worsen the office supply shortage, and hinder our efforts to attract financial institutions and other businesses who are thinking of setting up offices or expanding their existing operations in Singapore.

     MND and URA will continue to monitor the office market closely and when the supply situation improves, we will remove this restriction.

 

     Sir, the Member also asked whether my Ministry will publish information on available office space.  I would like to inform her that such information is already provided by property agents and consultants and are publicly available.  There is no need for the Government to duplicate their efforts.  However, what

Column: 697

we can and will do is to publish information on the new supply of office space in specific projects that will be completed over the next few years.  I hope the release of such additional information will improve the working of the office space market and facilitate the necessary market adjustments in supply going forward.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for the comprehensive response to my questions.

 

     Sir, I have two supplementary questions for the Minister: Would the Ministry consider some sort of a relocation grant to ease the burden of some of the SMEs who have actually been forced to shift because of redevelopment?   In view of the fact that from now till 2010, when there will be more supply of office space, in the interim, would the Minister consider liberalising the use of residential homes for some of these operations?

      Mr Mah Bow Tan:   Sir, the Member asked whether we would consider a relocation grant to ease the financial burdens of SMEs due to redevelopment.  If she is referring to the relocation of SMEs from existing commercial buildings, then this is something that the SMEs or the tenants have to take up and discuss with the landlords of the buildings themselves.  However, if it is a matter of relocating from Government premises, eg, SMEs relocating out of HDB industrial parks, yes, there are schemes that are in place which do provide some relocation grants. 


     As for the interim shortage of office space, as I have explained earlier, this is due to quite a severe imbalance in supply and demand.  The Ministry, as well as other Government agencies, is looking into various ways of meeting this

Column: 698

demand, especially in the short term.  And that is the reason why we have decided to allocate sites for transitional office space.  Whilst there is sufficient space coming on stream in 2010 and beyond, the problem is a shortage of space from now until 2010.  So, in order to try to meet that transitional shortage, we would like to offer such sites for transitional offices.  And, indeed, these offices are quite easy to build and also very comfortable.  I believe some Members may have visited the LTA offices in Kampong Java.  These offices were built very quickly and at a very low cost.  The people who are working there tell me that it is a very comfortable office to work in.  So that can help plug some of the gaps.


     For SMEs or small businesses who want to start up or who have difficulties looking for space, they are currently able to use residential premises for their office.  HDB has a Home Office Scheme.  The Home Office Scheme is very well taken up.  Anybody who would like to set up an office for two to three people, or who would like to experiment and start off on a very modest basis, can register their office using an HDB address.  In fact, many have already done so.  If the Member is interested, I would be happy to send her further information on this scheme.

     Ms Ellen Lee:  Sir, I just like to ask the Minister, when he mentioned about short-term leases, is he talking about leases below three years until 2010 when the supply is stabilised?  And what will happen to all these transitional offices once all these leases expire, because that would mean relocation and incurring more cost again for these businesses that have to relocate?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:   Sir, the Member is correct in pointing out that if the leases are too short, there will be disruption problems later on when the leases expire.  Similarly, if the leases are too short, then

Column: 699

it is not worthwhile for people to take up those leases.  So we are looking at a suitable lease which will not be too short but which will not be too long either that would cause the cost of the land to go up.  We are looking at something around 9-10 years' lease, renewable over two to three tranches.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):   Sir, I would like to know whether MND or any other Ministry has made an assessment of the impact of this rental hike: (a) on the survivability or cost of doing business for the small enterprises; and (b) on the price of consumer goods and services to the consumers.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, as far as the impact on the final price of goods and services to the consumers is concerned, the Ministry of Trade and Industry has a CPI index that it publishes regularly.  I believe that the overall impact on inflation so far, not just because of the shortage of space and rent hikes but many other things, is relatively mild.  I will leave MTI to announce the details.
     As far as the impact on cost of doing business is concerned, let me just point out for Members' benefit that although our office rental rates have gone up, in terms of the overall comparison with other major global business hubs in the world, we are still ranked relatively low.  Compared to, say, New York, London, Hong Kong, Tokyo, we are actually ranked quite far down the list.  In fact, I have got some figures here.  If I may share this with Members, there is a Global Office Occupancy Cost Survey that was done in January 2007, and it ranked Singapore number 55 in terms of overall office occupancy cost.  I think they define this "cost" to mean not just the cost of rental per se but also the cost of maintenance, property tax, and so on.  In terms of overall cost, we are number 55, way down the list.  London is number one, then Hong Kong, New York, Tokyo,

Column: 700

Seoul, and so on.  This is obviously something which we would like to monitor closely.  We do not want to price ourselves out of the market if the costs of doing business in Singapore are too high.  At the same time, I think we should also bear in mind that there is a limited amount of rabbits that the Government can pull out of its hat in terms of keeping costs down, especially when it comes to land cost, especially in a situation where land is in short supply.

SUB-SALE OF PRIVATE PROPERTIES IN CENTRAL AND OUTER CENTRAL REGIONS

     7.  Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he could provide an update on the sub-sale situation of private properties in the central region and the outer central region in the light of rising sub-sales compared to previous quarters of the year; (b) if there are policy gaps today to contain specu-investment; and (c) what measures are there to ensure that the property market remains healthy.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, there were 581 sub-sale transactions in the first quarter of 2007.  This is about the same as that in the fourth quarter of 2006.  Of the 581 transactions in the first quarter 2007, 368 or 63% were in the Core Central Region (CCR).  This Core Central Region consists of Districts 9, 10, 11, the Sentosa area as well as the Central Area.  Then, there were 156 sub-sale transactions or 27% in the Rest of Central Region (RCR) and 57 transactions or 10% Outside Central Region (OCR).  The figures for the fourth quarter of 2006 were about the same,


in other words, 66% of sub-sales were in the CCR, 20% in the RCR and 14% in the OCR.


     The higher level of sub-sale activity in the CCR compared to that in the RCR and OCR was due partly to the strong foreign interest in this segment of the property

Column: 701

market.  It is in line with the robust growth of our economy and reflects the confidence of foreigners and investors in the growth prospects of Singapore.


    The number of sub-sales in the first quarter of 2007 is still lower than that in 1996, when sub-sales reached a high of 1,700 per quarter and accounted for up to 28% of all private residential transactions in a quarter.  In comparison, sub-sales as a proportion of all private transactions in the first quarter of 2007 is 6.3%.


     Sir, I want to inform Members that sub-sale activity is only one of the many indicators that the Government keeps track of to ensure that the residential property market is healthy and growing in a sustainable manner.


     The Government also monitors the prices of private residential properties.  Recently, there have been media reports which cited developers achieving record sale prices for their projects.  While some of these high priced transactions do take place, I am concerned that such reports may not paint the full picture and as a result may mislead home purchasers.  For example, such record prices could be for a few choice units with special attributes and not be representative of the transacted prices for most of the units in the project.


     I have therefore asked URA to work with the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (REDAS) to see how we can give a fuller picture of the range of transacted prices for all newly launched private residential projects. This will further improve the transparency and efficiency of the Singapore property market and help buyers and sellers make more informed decisions.


     I want to assure Members that the Government will continue to monitor the

Column: 702

property market closely.  We will make sure that the market is as transparent as possible.  Finally, we will ensure that there is a sufficient supply of land for private housing to meet the demand in the various regions through the Government Land Sales Programme.

READY-MIX CONCRETE

(Price increase)

     The following Question stood in the name of Mr Charles Chong -

 

      8.  To ask the Minister for National Development, in light of the Indonesian export ban on land sand and the disruption of supply of granite (a) whether the price increase for ready-mix concrete is proportionate to the price of sand and aggregate supplies obtained from Government stockpiles; (b) how many ready-mix concrete suppliers are there in Singapore; and (c) whether there is any evidence of profiteering by ready-mix concrete suppliers and, if so, what immediate and long-term measures will the Ministry take to rectify this situation.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Question No. 8, Sir.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, the price of concrete is determined by the market.  Following the sudden disruption in the supplies of concreting sand and granite from Indonesia in February and March respectively, concrete price rose to about $200 per cubic metre.  This was due largely to the significantly higher prices of sand and granite and short term supply uncertainties. 


     Since then, the industry has adjusted to the market, including the sand and granite prices from alternative sources.  There is now greater supply and pricing clarity, and concrete price has fallen to below $175 per cubic metre.  I understand that the industry associations, including the Real Estate Developers' Association of

Column: 703

Singapore (REDAS), the Singapore Contractors Association Limited (SCAL), the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV), and the Ready-mix Concrete Association (RMCA) have come together to examine the cost structure of concrete production, and agreed on some principles on the cost-sharing arrangement for the increased costs of sand and granite for on-going projects.


     Currently, there are about 10 ready-mix concrete suppliers in the market.  I believe there is sufficient competition in the market of concrete.  However, the Government has released land for new concrete batching plants and, if necessary, is prepared to release more if there is demand for it.


     I assure the House that the Government will continue to monitor the situation closely, and will look at any specific feedback of cases of unjustified increase in concrete prices.

    Er Lee Bee Wah:  Two supplementary questions, Sir.  I understood that the Singapore Contractors Association Limited has submitted a thick file on evidence of profiteering.  May I ask whether the Ministry has responded to SCAL's submission?  My second question is this.  The Ministry has released the land, but what if it is awarded to the current player, will it help the situation?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Yes, I believe that SCAL has submitted some complaints on profiteering to the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) and BCA is looking into these specific complaints.  They have not reached the final conclusion on each of these complaints.  But as and when they do, I will make sure that the results of these complaints are released to the relevant parties.


     As for the land that has been released, I think the intention of the release of more land for batching plants is to increase the

Column: 704

number of players in the market, not to keep them at the same level or, worse still, to reduce the number of players.  So if that is the objective, then I think it would not serve the purpose for us to release such land to the existing players.  Having said that, if there are any complaints on profiteering, there are ample opportunities and avenues for the various complainants to bring their cases up, not only to the BCA.  I am sure the Competition Commission may want to have a look at it as well.  So, let us look at each of these complaints and see whether they are justified or not and, if they are, then I would like to assure the Member that action will be taken.

SUBSIDISED BEDS IN PUBLIC HOSPITALS

(Adequacy)

     9.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health, in view of the rapidly ageing population (a) whether there are enough subsidised beds for patients in public hospitals to meet the increasing demand; and (b) whether the Ministry has plans to increase the number of subsidised beds in public hospitals.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the supply of acute hospital beds must keep pace with increasing demand, as our resident population expands and ages.  We try to match supply and demand, but it is quite a challenge to do so perfectly given the long lead time in putting up new hospitals. 

 

     Our current bed situation is tight, particularly in the Tan Tock Seng Hospital as it is the only hospital serving the large population in the north besides its own large catchment area.  The over-crowding in Tan Tock Seng Hospital in turn causes spill-over to the other hospitals, especially National University Hospital and Changi General Hospital.  There will be relief when the new general hospital in Yishun opens in three years' time. 

 

Column: 705

     Meanwhile, we are adding new beds to existing hospitals.  Since the beginning of this year, we have added 81 beds in Tan Tock Seng Hospital and NUH.  All are subsidised beds.  Another 67 beds in NUH and Changi General Hospital will be opened in the second half of this year, ie, over the next few months, also in the subsidised wards.  We will continue the incremental expansion wherever practical until the new general hospital in Yishun opens.

 

     As our resident population will continue to expand and age, demand for new hospital beds will continue to rise even after the new general hospital is fully opened with 550 beds around 2012.  Our rough projections suggest that we will need 60-100 new beds per year until the population stabilises.  A significant proportion of these beds will be in the subsidised wards.  We are planning ahead.  A new general hospital in the west will be built during the next few years.  Otherwise, National University Hospital may become as over-crowded as Tan Tock Seng Hospital is today.  Our plan is to keep Alexandra Hospital temporarily for a few years while the new general hospital in the west is being built.  The exact timing and location are being studied.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister, pending the completion of the two hospitals which the Minister mentioned, how does the Ministry intend to deal with this shortage of total beds, whether the measure the Minister mentioned just now is sufficient to meet the shortage of beds in the subsidised wards?

      Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, as I said, the plan is to add in incrementally because patient demand does not increase suddenly to 500 beds in a few years' time.  It increased gradually, just as

Column: 706

population ages gradually every day.  So the rough projection of between 60 and 100 new beds per year should be adequate.  And I think the plan that we have added this year and next year should be able to meet the demand.  But let me make a word of caution here that for public hospitals, as I have explained in this House before, we try to run it on high occupancy because that is the only way to keep costs as low as it is feasible.  The easiest thing is to keep on adding beds but demand will simply swell to meet up.  By keeping beds a bit tight, it forces the administration to look out for areas of possible wastages, and eliminate them.  If I may give a simple example of day surgery - I remember introducing day surgery in public hospitals over 20 years ago when I was running NUH.  At that time, it was a new concept and habits had to change.  So the take-up was slow.  I am quite glad that more than 20 years later, today more surgeries are done as day surgeries than as inpatients.  That is a dramatic achievement.  But we have probably hit the maximum of what is possible for day surgeries.  In recent months, we begin to study what other medical treatments which may not require surgeries but which can be done on an outpatient basis. And each time we push the frontier, if we can save X% of hospitalisation, then we save a lot of costs both for the patient as well as for the society.  This is an important effort that we must continue to push on.

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Sembawang):   Mr Speaker, Sir, with the mentioning of means testing for hospitalisation by the Minister, I was just wondering whether the need for subsidised beds will be reduced with the introduction of means testing.  Can the Minister give us an update on the proposed means testing?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   Sir, means testing is always a topic at the top of my head, and it will continue to be at the top of my head.  But I have also many other urgent

Column: 707

matters to attend to.  So, in due course, we would address this issue.  The concept is simple: those who can afford less ought to be subsidised more than those who can afford more.  But translating it is not so simple.  Over the weekend, I have read Mdm Halimah's comments on this issue and we will take those into consideration when I am ready to explore this subject in greater detail.  But, meanwhile, I have still got many things to do - ElderShield reform, MediShield reform, etc. We will come to it in due course.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:   I want to thank the Minister for his explanation.  Because of this shortage of beds, there is a concern that patients could be turned around very quickly.  I would like to ask the Minister to give an assurance that


those who need treatment will be kept long enough in the hospital.  That is the concern on the ground.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, for us in this business of healthcare, our instinct is always to save life and not to do harm.  So I do not think doctors would be discharging patients before they are ready to be discharged.  A lot of times, the pressure is on where we know we have done all we can for the patients in an acute hospital setting, and the patients can be competently handled in a community hospital or nursing home.  That is where the discharge is all about, where we are worried about "abuse" - if I may use that word - of expensive acute hospital.  When the acute episode is over and we have done what we can, say after surgery and the patient may need a few more days of recovery but can be adequately managed in a community hospital, our preference is to move that patient from a very expensive acute hospital - expensive both to the patient as well as to society at large - to a nursing home or community hospital.  But, currently, the pricing sometimes skews the outcome, because they may

Column: 708

find that SGH is so cheap and the consultants are there, even though they know they could be adequately handled, say, in Ang Mo Kio Community Hospital.  But they say, "Please, can we stay one, two or three more days?"  But each time we allow that, there are patients waiting in the emergency department, new patients with acute medical conditions, who can benefit from the use of that bed.  That is the sort of trade-off which we have to do, and we hope patients will continue to be cooperative.  But, I think if we price it rightly, they can be more readily cooperative.

CLASS B2 AND C WARDS IN PUBLIC HOSPITALS

(Shortage of beds)

     10.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for Health (a) whether the Ministry will consider providing non-air-conditioned Class B1 wards in public hospitals as many elderly patients are uncomfortable with air-conditioning and there is a shortage of beds in Class B2 and C wards; and (b) what is the Ministry's plan to solve the shortage of beds in Class B2 and C wards of our public hospitals.

     The Minister of State for Health (Mr Heng Chee How) (for the Minister for Health):  Mr Speaker, Sir, as my Minister has just replied to Mdm Halimah on how the Ministry of Health intends to meet the rising demand for subsidised beds, I will not repeat that part.

 

     The first part of Mdm Cynthia Phua's Question relates to the provision of non-airconditioned Class B1 wards.  On that subject, we do receive an occasional request, but when we look at it in proportion to the requirements that most patients going into B1 ask for, then it does not amount to a strong demand.  Our feedback has in fact been that many patients opt for B1 wards precisely for

Column: 709

their air-conditioned comfort.  As the request is generally caused by the shortage of Class B2 wards and the beds there, we will focus on adding more B2 beds as a more meaningful solution.

     Mr Heng Chee How:  Mr Speaker, Sir, for B2 and C class wards, they are not air-conditioned.  In the case of B1 wards, there are four beds in each room and they are air-conditioned.  Not everybody is averse to air-conditioning.  In fact, we have found out that the majority of people look for air-conditioned comfort as well.  In the current setting, those who feel that they might need an extra blanket or so are certainly given one.  For Class A1 wards, they are single-bedded and they are able to adjust the temperature in their own rooms according to the thermostat.

 

     With regard to the new hospital in the north, as my Minister has explained, new beds are certainly going to be made available there up to 550, most of which would be subsidised beds.  In the B2 and C class wards, that would not be a problem.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua:  Mr Speaker, Sir, with the principle of means-testing, which means that if people can afford a better ward, eg, B1, with better medical attention, in such a case, an elderly resident who is averse to air-conditioning may want a higher medical attention ward but without air-conditioning.  What I am saying is that we are now going into a

Column: 710

growing elderly population.  This is a demand from the residents as well.

     Mr Heng Chee How:  Mr Speaker, Sir, our feedback has been that, currently, patients who opt for B1, many prefer the air-conditioned comfort.  But, in the same breath, I would say that we continue to take in the feedback.  If the demography changes and the demand patterns change, we certainly would take that into account in the configuration of the amenities that we provide.

JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN SINGAPORE

(Assistance to foreigners to take up)

     11.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what are the Ministry's plans to fill jobs with foreign and guest workers in light of the Singapore economy expecting to generate some 450,000 jobs in the next five years and the local workforce only filling half of these jobs; and (b) what efforts are being made to identify and help foreigners to come to Singapore to take up these jobs.     

     The Minister of State for Manpower (Mr Gan Kim Yong) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Mr Speaker, Sir, our foreign worker policies are designed to be flexible and responsive to the demands of the market.  The Government does not supply foreign workers to companies, but leaves it to them to recruit from various sources.  MOM ensures that the prevailing foreign worker quotas are realistic, given the state of the economy. 


     As mentioned during MOM's Committee of Supply debate, we should not limit the growth of our economy only to what the local workforce can sustain.  Various measures were also announced then.  For example, the S Pass quota will be raised from 10% to 15% from 1st June 2007 to give businesses more access to mid-skilled manpower.  Certain regulations in the construction and

Column: 711

process sectors have also been eased to help meet the anticipated manpower needs, given the upcoming big projects.  All these measures will help businesses meet their manpower needs.


     Mdm Ho also asked what efforts are being made to identify and help foreigners to come to Singapore to take up these jobs.  While the Government does not perform a job-matching service for foreign workers, we recognise that it is important in this era of global competition for talent, that we help companies by promoting Singapore to overseas talent.  Our Employment Pass framework facilitates the entry of global talent recruited by companies, and there are no quota restrictions.  MOM recently introduced the Personalised Employment Pass (PEP) to better attract and retain talented foreign professionals.  There are already more than 700 PEP holders.  In addition, Contact Singapore helps Singapore-based employers and economic agencies reach out to targeted talent groups overseas.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo:  Sir, I have three supplementary questions for the MOS:

 

     (1)  What kind of guidelines is the Ministry drawing up to ensure that there will be organised programmes to bring about a more consistent performance standard among foreigners who come to work in Singapore?

 

     (2)  What is the Ministry doing with regard to programmes on integrating foreigners with the Singaporean workforce?  and

 

     (3)  How does the Ministry go about ensuring that the foreign workforce in Singapore would be protected from unscrupulous employers?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, MOM has always been working very closely with our tripartite partners, ie, the NTUC, WDA, as well as the Singapore

Column: 712

National Employers Federation, to look at how we could help train our foreign workers to prepare them better for the environment in Singapore.  We also produce guidelines for both employers as well as employees, to help them integrate into our society so that they find their experience working in Singapore a pleasant one.  Only by doing so will we be able to attract more foreign talent and to retain them in Singapore.

 

     With regard to the last question on the protection of foreign workers, in fact, this has been a key focus of MOM over the years, and we want to make sure that for the foreign workers who are here to contribute to our economy, their interests are protected no less than our Singaporean workers.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad:  Mr Speaker, Sir, a couple of supplementary questions:

 

     (1)  I know a lot of these jobs that we are trying to fill consist of a lot of mid-skilled and PMET jobs.  What are the priority areas that the Ministry is looking at to upskill Singaporeans to fill in this higher-value job set?

 

     (2)  Do we have a projected percentage that we are looking to fill with Singaporeans, since we are also looking at a lot of these foreign jobs?  and

 

     (3)  What is being done to ensure that Singaporeans are not left out of these jobs, particularly the higher value-added and PMET jobs?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, indeed, it is one of our key concerns to ensure that our Singaporeans will continue to be able to find good jobs as we create new opportunities for them.  With regard specifically to PMETs, we announced recently the introduction of a professional conversion programme and this is targeted at mid-skilled Singaporeans, to train them for specific sectors that we foresee would have a

Column: 713

rising demand.  Through this conversion programme, we will help them to switch careers and equip them with the skills necessary for these new sectors of growth.  This is one example, and we will continue to help them.  But we also have to recognise that some of these PMET employees have their own individual needs which are different from the general workers.  So we need to hold their hands more closely.  We will find ways to help them as we go along. 

 

     With regard to Mr Zaqy's second question on the projected numbers that we are expecting to fill, either through the education system or future workforce, in terms of our projection, we mentioned that, over the next five years, we are going to create some 450,000 job opportunities.  Among these 450,000 job opportunities that we are going to create, we do not have specific targets, because these are macro numbers.  But we do believe that, because most of these jobs will be service-related and in the service sector in Singapore, by and large, the majority will continue to be Singaporeans and, therefore, most of these jobs will be Singaporean-based.

Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Police Coast Guard (PCG) plays an important role in safeguarding Singapore's sea borders, patrolling our territorial waters to detect intrusion by terrorists, smuggling of explosives and weapons for terrorist operations, as well as illegal immigrants and smugglers of other contraband items.

 

Column: 715

     Whilst operational safety is of utmost importance to the PCG, there are inherent risks involved in maritime operations, such as high winds, strong sea waves and high speed manoeuvring in the night.  These risks increase when intercepting and repelling intrusions, as high speeds are normally required, especially when the intruding vessel refuses to stop, or is persistent in trying to evade arrest.  The possible presence of other vessels and sea hazards in our waters adds to these risks, especially in the hours of darkness. 

 

     Therefore, despite the thorough training our PCG officers receive and the use of safety equipment, such as radar and night vision devices on board our PCG boats to facilitate navigation and surveillance, there is a risk of lives being lost in an operation.

 

     Sir, with regard to the recent incident on 13th April 2007 where two PCG officers died, the Singapore Police Force is currently conducting investigations into the incident for the Coroner's Inquiry which will be held in due course.  It is therefore not appropriate for me to discuss the details of the case at this stage.  Separately, the Ministry of Home Affairs will be reviewing the facts and circumstances leading to the incident, to assess if we can create a safer operating environment for PCG officers when performing their duties at sea.  The review will cover the anti-intrusion tactics, training and equipment.

 

     But let me say, Sir, that MHA takes a very serious view of this incident and will take all necessary measures to rectify any problems that may be identified.

Member may know that in 1995, we secured the PK classes of boats which can reach top speeds of 50 knots.


In terms of speed for speed, they can actually take these boats on.  Of course, these boats are smaller and, therefore, in the darkness of the night, they will try to manoeuvre and, in trying to evade arrest, may try to make turns.  So, this normally happens.  I will not comment on this case, but this is likely to have happened.

POLICE OFFICERS KILLED IN THE COURSE OF DUTY

(Compensation to next-of-kin)

     14.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs what amount or range of compensation is paid by the Government to the next-of-kin of police officers who are killed in the course of duty.

Column: 717

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, every case of a police officer killed in the line of duty is indeed a sad one.  Our sympathies are with the bereaved families.  These officers had put their lives at risk to keep Singapore safe.

 

     When an officer dies in the course of his work, every effort is taken to ensure that the officer's next-of-kin is taken care of, not only in terms of monetary compensation, but also through psychological and welfare support.

 

      The Pensions Act, together with the Pensions Regulations and the Home Affairs Uniformed Services (HUS) (INVEST Plan) Regulations, depending on which scheme of service the officer is on, ensures that the officer's family is adequately compensated.

 

      Sir, for officers on the Pension scheme, there is a death gratuity lump-sum, the quantum of which would depend on the officer's last drawn salary. For officers on the HUS (INVEST) scheme, the officer's family will receive the total balance in the officer's INVEST Retention and Retirement Accounts or one year's salary, whichever is higher.  In addition to these payments, the officer's family may also receive a payout of up to $111,000 under the Workmen's Compensation Act.

 

     Sir, for married officers, the officer's widow will receive monthly dependents' pension of one-third of the officer's pensionable emoluments, and his children, up to 18 years of age, will receive monthly dependents' pension of one-fifteenth of the officer's pensionable emoluments. 

 

    On top of all these, officers are also covered under a basic group term life insurance and personal accident insurance package, with a payout of $180,000 for deaths.  Officers who had opted for additional coverage will receive higher payouts. 

 

Column: 718

     The Police Central Welfare Fund will also provide the families an immediate bereavement grant of $4,000 to help defray the cost of the funeral arrangements as well as, for the longer term, provide annual grants for the officer's children's education.

 

    In addition to these monetary compensation items, the SPF provides emotional and psychological support through its psychologists and trained paracounsellors.  They will be in touch with the officer's family right from the onset.  Colleagues and paracounsellors from the officer's unit will also provide logistical and emotional support during the funeral wake and indeed thereafter.

 

    Sir, as losing a police officer in the line of duty is indeed tragic, let me assure Ms Lim that we will provide all means of assistance to help the officer's family when it happens.

"BRING YOUR OWN BAG" CAMPAIGN

(Impact)

     16.  Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources what impact does the "Bring Your Own Bag" campaign have on the plastic bag industry and will the push to reduce plastic bag usage result in potential problems of refuse collection as most  residents are encouraged to throw refuse in plastic bags.

     The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim):  Mr Speaker, Sir, Singaporeans use about 2.5 billion plastic bags each year for bagging their purchases. This is equivalent to about 19,000 tonnes of plastic or 0.8% of the total waste disposed of in Singapore annually.  Unlike in most countries where plastic bags remain in landfills for years, plastic bags in Singapore are incinerated in our waste-to-energy plants to recover energy.


     As pointed out by Dr Lim, many households re-use plastic bags to bag their refuse.  This is a good hygiene practice as it prevents spillage when refuse is collected by our waste collectors.  Our refuse is usually wet and, in our warm tropical climate, tends to putrefy rapidly, resulting in smell nuisance.  Unbagged refuse also attracts pests.  The majority of Singaporeans live in high-rise buildings, so bagging our refuse helps to keep the refuse chutes clean and hygienic.  Sir, my Ministry has been advocating the practice of re-using plastic bags to bag household refuse and will continue to do so.


Column: 721

     Thus, we will not phase out the use of plastic bags now or in the future.  However, Sir, we are concerned with excessive and wasteful use of plastic bags.  Thus, the National Environment Agency launched the "Why waste plastic bags? Use reusable bags!" campaign in February 2006 to promote the use of reusable bags and reduce the wastage of plastic bags.


     More recently, in April 2007, the "Bring Your Own Bag" campaign was also launched in partnership with the Singapore Environment Council and major supermarkets and retailers.  Under this campaign, on the first Wednesday of the month, shoppers who do not bring their own shopping bags are encouraged to donate 10 cents for each plastic bag taken at the check-out counters.  The "Bring Your Own Bag" campaign should not have any significant impact on the plastic bag industry as we are not banning plastic bags totally but discouraging the excessive and unnecessary use of plastic bags.

     17.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, against the backdrop of plans to make our waterways active, beautiful and clean, what safety measures are being considered in light of the recent cases where students were swept away by strong currents in canals and whether there are warning signs along these canals to warn the public of the danger of a sudden rise in the water level.

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, I thank Mr Seah for supporting us.


    Sir, canals and waterways in Singapore are built to convey stormwater during heavy rains.  This flood-alleviation function remains important even as we embark upon the ABC Waters Programme.  Hence, we have to put in place a system to ensure the safety of the public as they enjoy the waters and get closer to it.  While we may landscape some rivers and canals to make them more aesthetically pleasing and bring people closer to the water, this does not necessarily mean that all our canals and waterways are safe for water activities.


     In considering whether to allow water activities in certain stretches of our

Column: 723

waterways, we conduct engineering assessments on the flow speed of the water during a storm and the ease of disembarking from the river banks.  All ABC Waters Projects are designed with public safety as our foremost concern.  Firstly, safety to users is a key design criterion for our consultants, who need to ensure that safety measures are an integral part of their project design.  The safety measures are further reviewed by PUB's safety committee which is chaired by the CEO.


     We strive to create designs that are attractive yet safe.  Allow me to show you an example.  In the case of Alexandra Canal, where the decking on top of the canal will consist of shallow flowing stream with water play areas, while the main canal beneath the decking allows stormwater to flow.  Also, metal railings can be replaced by alternative forms of barriers, such as earth mounds or shrubs, along the water edges.


     To allow water users, such as boaters or kayakers, to evacuate from the waters safely, gentle sloping embankments or evacuation points will be incorporated.  These will be complemented by a siren warning system to alert water users, should there be a need to evacuate them.  Warning signs and life buoys will also be put up at strategic locations along the canals.


     All water activities in waterways will be managed through an appointed operator (or organiser), who will manage and oversee the water users to ensure that the activities are carried out properly in accordance with safety procedures.  The operator will conduct safety briefings before the commencement of activities, and ensure that safety SOPs are observed, such as the wearing of life vests.


     While safety measures have been put in place, the public should exercise
